page.title: 03FARMING IN EAST MONKLANDS 1
page.content: THE EAST MONKLANDS IS ESSENTIALLY A {MARGINAL FARMING}AREA. ITS ELEVATION OF OVER 200 METRES MAKES IT RATHER EXPOSED AND WET. MOST OF THE AREA HAS A HEAVY CLAY SOIL WITH A LOW ORGANIC CONTENT, WHILE TO THE NORTH EAST, THE LAND IS BADLY DRAINED PEATY MOORLAND. THERE ARE A FEW EXCEPTIONS OF FREE-STONE SOIL WHICH USED TO BE DEVOTED TO THE CULTIVATION OF POTATOES AND CEREALS. MOST OF THE FARMS IN THE AREA ARE RELATIVELY SMALL AND IN THE PAST WERE{SELF-SUFFICIENT MIXED FARMS} CONCENTRATING ON{DAIRY FARMING AND {POULTRY.}MOST OF THE MILK PRODUCED WAS TO MEET LOCAL DEMAND. SOME FARMS CONCENTRATED ON THE GROWING OF HAY E.G.DRUMSHANGIE FARM (777688) TO SUPPLY THE HORSE POPULATION OF GLASGOW WHEN HORSE TRANSPORT WAS STILL AT A PEAK.
